answer:
<p>It was pointed out that <code>1i</code> is an acceptable and unambiguous way to write <code>sqrt(-1)</code>, and that as such there is no need to avoid using <code>i</code>. Then again, as <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/14790740/using-i-and-j-as-variables-in-matlab/14893729#14893729">Dennis pointed out</a>, it can be hard to see the difference between <code>1i</code> and <code>ii</code>. My suggestion: use <code>1j</code> as the imaginary constant where possible. It's the same trick that electrical engineers employ - they use <code>j</code> for <code>sqrt(-1)</code> because <code>i</code> is already taken for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electric_current" rel="nofollow noreferrer">current</a>.</p>
<p>Personally I never use <code>i</code> and <code>j</code>; I use <code>ii</code> and <code>jj</code> as shorthand indexing variables, (and kk, ll, mm, ...) and <code>1j</code> when I need to use complex numbers.</p>

<p>By default <code>i</code> and <code>j</code> stand for the imaginary unit. So from MATLAB's point of view, using <code>i</code> as a variable is somehow like using <code>1</code> as a variable.</p>

<p>Any non-trivial code contains multiple <code>for</code> loops, and the best practices recommend you use a descriptive name indicative of its purpose and scope. For times immemorial (and unless its 5-10 lines script that I am not going to save),  I have always been using variable names like <code>idxTask</code>, <code>idxAnotherTask</code> and <code>idxSubTask</code> etc. </p>

<p>Or at the very least doubling the first letter of the array it is indexing e.g. <code>ss</code> to index <code>subjectList</code>, <code>tt</code> to index <code>taskList</code>, but not <code>ii</code> or <code>jj</code> which doesn't help me effortlessly identify which array they are indexing out of my multiple for loops.</p>
data.title: Using i and j as variables in MATLAB
